```js `` *   Date time formats: are date formats followed by time formats.               *   For example (longest): `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ` `` ```

````` Instead of `Z` (which is UTC+0), we can also specify *time offsets* relative to UTC:    *   `THH:mm+HH:mm` (etc.) *   `THH:mm-HH:mm` (etc.)    #### [47.3.1 Tip: append a `Z` to make date parsing deterministic](#tip-append-a-z-to-make-date-parsing-deterministic)    If we add a `Z` to the end of a string, date parsing doesn’t produce different results at different locations. This is what happens if we write code in Paris:    *   Without `Z`: Input is January 27 (implicitly in the Europe/Paris time zone), output is January 26 (in UTC).                    ```js     > new Date('2077-01-27T00:00').toISOString()     '2077-01-26T23:00:00.000Z'          ```           *   With `Z`: Input is January 27, output is January 27.                    ```js     > new Date('2077-01-27T00:00Z').toISOString()     '2077-01-27T00:00:00.000Z'          ```              ### [47.4 Time values](#time-values)    A *time value* represents a date via the number of milliseconds since 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC.    Time values can be used to create Dates:    ```js const timeValue = 0; assert.equal(  new Date(timeValue).toISOString(),  '1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z');  ```    Coercing a Date to a number returns its time value:    ```js > Number(new Date(123)) 123  ```    Ordering operators coerce their operands to numbers. Therefore, we can use these operators to compare Dates:    ```js assert.equal(  new Date('1972-05-03') < new Date('2001-12-23'), true);  `// Internally:` `assert.equal(73699200000 < 1009065600000, true);`  ```   ```js` #### [47.4.1 Creating time values](#creating-time-values)    The following methods create time values:    *   `Date.now(): number` (UTC)                    Returns the current time as a time value.           *   `Date.parse(dateTimeStr: string): number` (local time zone, UTC, time offset)                    Parses `dateTimeStr` and returns the corresponding time value.           *   `Date.UTC(year, month, date?, hours?, minutes?, seconds?, milliseconds?): number` (UTC)                    Returns the time value for the specified UTC date time.              #### [47.4.2 Getting and setting time values](#getting-and-setting-time-values)    *   `Date.prototype.getTime(): number` (UTC)                    Returns the time value corresponding to the Date.           *   `Date.prototype.setTime(timeValue)` (UTC)                    Sets `this` to the date encoded by `timeValue`.              ### [47.5 Creating Dates](#creating-dates)    #### [47.5.1 Creating dates via numbers](#creating-dates-via-numbers)    `new Date(year: number, month: number, date?: number, hours?: number, minutes?: number, seconds?: number, milliseconds?: number)` (local time zone)    Two of the parameters have pitfalls:    *   For `month`, 0 is January, 1 is February, etc.           *   If 0 ≤ `year` ≤ 99, then 1900 is added:                    ```     > new Date(12, 1, 22, 19, 11).getFullYear()     1912          ```js                    That’s why, elsewhere in this chapter, we avoid the time unit `year` and always use `fullYear`. But in this case, we have no choice.              Example:    ``` > new Date(2077,0,27, 21,49).toISOString() // CET (UTC+1) '2077-01-27T20:49:00.000Z'  ```js    Note that the input hours (21) are different from the output hours (20). The former refer to the local time zone, the latter to UTC.    #### [47.5.2 Parsing dates from strings](#parsing-dates-from-strings)    `new Date(dateTimeStr: string)` (local time zone, UTC, time offset)    If there is a `Z` at the end, UTC is used:    ``` > new Date('2077-01-27T00:00Z').toISOString() '2077-01-27T00:00:00.000Z'  ```js    If there is no `Z` or time offset at the end, the local time zone is used:    ``` > new Date('2077-01-27T00:00').toISOString() // CET (UTC+1) '2077-01-26T23:00:00.000Z'  ```js    If a string only contains a date, it is interpreted as UTC:    ``` > new Date('2077-01-27').toISOString() '2077-01-27T00:00:00.000Z'  ```js    #### [47.5.3 Other ways of creating dates](#other-ways-of-creating-dates)    *   `new Date(timeValue: number)` (UTC)                    ```     > new Date(0).toISOString()     '1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z'          ```js           *   `new Date()` (UTC)                    The same as `new Date(Date.now())`.              ### [47.6 Getters and setters](#getters-and-setters)    #### [47.6.1 Time unit getters and setters](#time-unit-getters-and-setters)    Dates have getters and setters for time units – for example:    *   `Date.prototype.getFullYear()` *   `Date.prototype.setFullYear(num)`    These getters and setters conform to the following patterns:    *   Local time zone:     *   `Date.prototype.get«Unit»()`     *   `Date.prototype.set«Unit»(num)` *   UTC:     *   `Date.prototype.getUTC«Unit»()`     *   `Date.prototype.setUTC«Unit»(num)`    These are the time units that are supported:    *   Date     *   `FullYear`     *   `Month`: month (0–11). **Pitfall:** 0 is January, etc.     *   `Date`: day of the month (1–31)     *   `Day` (getter only): day of the week (0–6, 0 is Sunday) *   Time     *   `Hours`: hour (0–23)     *   `Minutes`: minutes (0–59)     *   `Seconds`: seconds (0–59)     *   `Milliseconds`: milliseconds (0–999)    There is one more getter that doesn’t conform to the previously mentioned patterns:    *   `Date.prototype.getTimezoneOffset()`                    Returns the time difference between local time zone and UTC in minutes. For example, for Europe/Paris, it returns `-120` (CEST, Central European Summer Time) or `-60` (CET, Central European Time):                    ```     > new Date('2122-06-29').getTimezoneOffset()     -120     > new Date('2122-12-29').getTimezoneOffset()     -60          ```js              ### [47.7 Converting Dates to strings](#converting-dates-to-strings)    Example Date:    ``` const d = new Date(0);  ```js    #### [47.7.1 Strings with times](#strings-with-times)    *   `Date.prototype.toTimeString()` (local time zone)                    ```     > d.toTimeString()     '01:00:00 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)'          ```js              #### [47.7.2 Strings with dates](#strings-with-dates)    *   `Date.prototype.toDateString()` (local time zone)                    ```     > d.toDateString()     'Thu Jan 01 1970'          ```js              #### [47.7.3 Strings with dates and times](#strings-with-dates-and-times)    *   `Date.prototype.toString()` (local time zone)                    ```     > d.toString()     'Thu Jan 01 1970 01:00:00 GMT+0100 (Central European Standard Time)'          ```js           *   `Date.prototype.toUTCString()` (UTC)                    ```     > d.toUTCString()     'Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT'          ```js           *   `Date.prototype.toISOString()` (UTC)                    ```     > d.toISOString()     '1970-01-01T00:00:00.000Z'          ```js              #### [47.7.4 Other methods](#other-methods)    The following three methods are not really part of ECMAScript, but rather of [the ECMAScript internationalization API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl). That API has much functionality for formatting dates (including support for time zones), but not for parsing them.    *   `Date.prototype.toLocaleTimeString()` *   `Date.prototype.toLocaleDateString()` *   `Date.prototype.toLocaleString()`    ![Icon “exercise”](../Images/4fc2ec98bb44cc1f4de7c6a46d9dd043.png) **Exercise: Creating a date string**    `exercises/dates/create_date_string_test.mjs` ```` ```js`` `````
